thread.title: Air France flight to Paris makes emergency landing after cracked windshield
thread.title_full: Air France flight to Paris makes emergency landing after cracked windshield | Daily Mail Online

author: John Hutchinson for MailOnline
title: Air France flight to Paris makes emergency landing after cracked windshield
text:
113 shares 38
View
comments
An Air France flight from Newcastle to Paris was forced to return to the north east this afternoon after suffering a cracked windshield.
Flight AF1059 was only minutes into the journey when the pilot signalled an emergency over the Peak District, and turned back to Newcastle.
Speculation on social media said that the crack in the windscreen was due to a bird strike on take-off, although that is yet to be confirmed.
An Air France flight scheduled for Paris was forced to return to Newcastle due to a cracked windshield
The Avro Avroliner RJ-85 made a safe landing back in the north east. It is unknown what time the aircraft will continue its journey on to Paris Charles de Gaulle.
Air France confirmed on Twitter that it was a 'normal procedure' due to a minor technical problem of a 'cracked windshield.'

Thieves pretending to be wealthy Arab tourists burgled hotel... Southwest Airlines plane has 'chunk' of wing tip torn off as... Share this article Share 113 shares Earlier this month a passenger jet was forced to burn off fuel and return to Liverpool Airport after suffering a bird strike on take-off.
Blue Air flight 134 took off in the morning from the north west at 10am, yet within minutes of being airborne, the pilot was alerted that there had been a bird strike.
The plane was then forced to circle back to Liverpool for around two hours as the pilot burnt off fuel in order to make a safe landing.
The Avro Avrolinerhad just flown over the Peak District when the pilot signalled an emergency
Earlier this year when discussing how serious bird strikes are on planes, Captain Steve Draper told MailOnline Travel: 'The vast majority of bird strike incidents take place during take-off and landing phases - so fairly near the ground, although birds have been occasionally hit at higher altitudes.
'On the whole the majority of air strikes occur below 3,000ft above ground, although there have been incidents occurring at higher altitudes.
'This is simply due to the face that above 10,000ft there are a reduced number of birds, but this hasn't stopped it happening at 30,000ft and higher.'
The Air France flight made a safe landing at Newcastle Airport this afternoon after a 'technical fault'
